A hotbed of political manoeuvring, ostentatious displays of power, and sneering contempt from the "old blood" families who could trace their lineage back to Merlin's gardener. It was a place for warlocks who wore velvet, not denim. For sorcerers who summered in pocket dimensions, not Skegness. It was everything he despised about the magical world, all concentrated into one night of forced pleasantries and arcane one-upmanship.

And he'd been invited.

Gripper, sensing the shift in his mood, let out a soft, questioning caw. Kevin lifted his head. "It's an invitation, you feathered menace. To a party. A big, stupid, fancy dress party for people who think they're better than us."

He swilled the dregs around, but the words held fast. This wasn't a trick of the light or a misinterpretation. This was a summons. He could, in theory, ignore it. He could smash the mug, make another brew, and get on with his day. But he knew it wasn't that simple. An invitation from the Penumbral Covenant wasn't a suggestion. It was a command wrapped in polite calligraphy. Ignoring it would draw more attention than attending. It would mark him as defiant, a rogue element. They'd send someone to 'enquire' as to his health, and those enquiries were rarely pleasant.

But why? Why him? He was nobody. A provincial warlock with a knack for unblocking enchanted drains. He hadn't attended a formal gathering in fifteen years, not since the disastrous Northern Conclave where his attempt to demonstrate a simple weather-calming charm had accidentally flash-flooded the entire Wigan Borough Council car park. He kept his head down. He paid his dues to the Covenant—a nominal fee, payable in crystallised moonbeams or, in his case, a dozen magically reinforced pies from Galloways bakery—and they left him alone. That was the deal.

His mind churned, sifting through possibilities. Was it a clerical error? Had the summons been meant for some other K. Barlow, some Kensington-based necromancer with a similar name? Unlikely. Magical post was notoriously accurate. Was it a joke? A cruel prank by one of the flashier Manchester warlocks he occasionally had to deal with? Possible, but the power thrumming from the teacup felt ancient and deeply serious. That left the most unsettling option: he had been chosen for a reason.

A name surfaced in his memory, unbidden and unwelcome. A name he'd heard whispered in the shadowed corners of the few magical pubs he dared to frequent. Alastor Blackwood. They called him the Plastimancer, the Bagman. A warlock of the new age, they said. A visionary. Kevin thought he was a bloody menace. Blackwood’s philosophy was the antithesis of his own. Where Kevin drew power from things of substance and history—brick, iron, earth—Blackwood harvested his from the discarded, the disposable, the ephemeral. His magic was the rustle of a carrier bag caught in a gale, the chemical sheen on a forgotten water bottle, the suffocating permanence of a landfill. He saw power in the things society threw away, a vast and ever-growing resource.

The established magical community was divided. The old families thought him vulgar, a grubby little upstart dabbling in metaphysical filth. But others, the younger, more ambitious ones, saw his point. Why bother tending to a thousand-year-old oak tree for a trickle of ambient energy when a single city's daily plastic waste held the trapped potential of a million forgotten moments? The moment a sandwich was bought and eaten, the moment a gift was unwrapped, the moment an impulse purchase was carried home. All that fleeting human energy, sealed in plastic. Blackwood had found a way to tap it. To refine it. To weaponise it. His rise had been meteoric and deeply unsettling.

Could this be about him? Was the Covenant finally taking the threat of Blackwood seriously? Perhaps they were gathering allies, even ones as seemingly insignificant as himself. Maybe they needed his specific, grounded expertise. A specialist in the magic of the mundane, to counter a man who had weaponised it. The thought was both flattering and terrifying. It made a horrible kind of sense.

He stood up and walked to the window, pulling the net curtain aside. The rain had intensified, lashing against the glass. The street outside was deserted, the slate roofs of the opposite houses shining like wet sealskin. The world looked grey, washed-out, utterly normal. Yet in the bottom of his teacup, a doorway to another world had opened, a world of intrigue and danger he had spent his entire adult life trying to avoid.

With a flick of his wrist, a gesture so practiced it was barely conscious, he sent a thread of his own power into the mug. The tea leaves dissolved instantly, turning the remaining liquid black before it faded to nothing, leaving the porcelain clean. The summons was gone from the cup, but it was now burned into his mind. He could feel its weight, a binding contract.

Gripper fluttered from his perch and landed on his shoulder, an unusual gesture of comfort. The magpie nudged its head against his cheek, its beak cold against his skin.

"Right then," Kevin said softly, to the bird, to the empty room, to the rainy Wigan street outside. "Looks like we're going to a ball."

He needed a suit. The very thought was exhausting. The Umbral Ball operated on a strict, if unspoken, dress code of "ostentatious wizardry." Think silks that whispered forgotten secrets, velvet woven from midnight itself, and jewellery that pulsed with captured starlight. The last time Kevin had worn a suit was for his cousin's wedding fifteen years ago, a heavy, ill-fitting polyester thing that had smelled faintly of mothballs and regret. It was probably still in the back of the wardrobe, patiently waiting to be fashionable again in some far-flung, tasteless future.

He opened the wardrobe door, unleashing a cascade of crumpled shirts, a single, forlorn sock, and the dusty scent of time. There it was, squashed between a thick winter coat and an old donkey jacket. He pulled it out. It was even worse than he remembered. The fabric had a slight, unnatural sheen, and the cut was wide enough to accommodate a second, much smaller Kevin. It wouldn't just make him look like a provincial hedge-mage who’d got lost on his way to a job interview; it would scream it through a magically amplified megaphone. Still, it was all he had. Make do and mend.

"Right," he announced to Gripper, who was watching from the top of the wardrobe with the intense focus of a bomb disposal expert. "Operation: Not Look Like a Total Pillock." He laid the suit out on his bed. The task was twofold. First, it needed to fit. Second, it needed to look less like something you'd win at a funfair. He ran his hands over the cheap fabric, closing his eyes and extending his senses. He didn't have the kind of power that could transfigure polyester into silk, but he could work with what was there. He reached for the inherent properties of the material, its synthetic, stubborn nature, its memory of the factory and the chemical processes that birthed it. He whispered a quiet, forceful charm, a warlock's plea for alteration. The suit twitched. Seams tightened, the ridiculously wide lapels narrowed, and the trousers reshaped themselves to something approaching a modern cut. It was still polyester, but now it was his polyester.

Next, the colour. It was a washed-out, depressing grey. He needed black. Proper black. Not the absence of light, but the presence of substance. He went back to the kitchen and returned with a small, soot-stained tin. Inside was a collection of charcoal sticks, salvaged from the cold hearths of pubs and the sites of old bonfires. Each one was saturated with the lingering energy of stories told, of songs sung, of warmth shared. He chose one, a dense piece taken from the fireplace of The Crooked Man, a pub so old its foundations were rumoured to be laid on a sleeping barrow-wight. He gently crushed it to a fine powder in his palm and blew it across the jacket. The dust didn't settle on the fabric; it sank into it. The grey vanished, consumed by a deep, matte black that seemed to drink the light in the room. It was the black of a worked-out coal seam, the black of a starless night over the slag heaps. It would have to do.

Throughout the process, Gripper offered his assistance by repeatedly attempting to steal the jacket's plastic buttons. Each time, Kevin would gently bat his beak away. On the fourth attempt, he sighed, pulled a dull brass button from a jar on his dresser, and flicked it into the corner. The bird squawked in triumph and scrambled after his prize, leaving Kevin to his work. He finished by reinforcing the pockets with a charm of containment, a necessary precaution for a party full of mages and a familiar with sticky claws. He held the finished article up. It wasn't velvet, and it certainly wasn't stylish, but it had a certain gravitas now. It looked like it belonged to him. It looked like it had history. It looked like Wigan.

The question of transport remained a mystery. The summons had been a declaration, not a set of directions. He suspected it was a test of sorts, or simply a feature of the Covenant’s high-handed magic. You didn't travel to the Umbral Ball; you were collected. He imagined a carriage of polished bone pulled by nightmares, or a shimmering portal opening in his living room. He hoped it wasn't the latter; he'd just got the rug settled. All he could do was be ready. He packed a small leather tool roll, a habit he couldn't break. Inside, he placed not wands or crystals, but his own implements: a spool of copper wire charmed to detect falsehoods, a wrench that could tighten or loosen metaphysical bonds, a small tin of purified grease for soothing agitated spirits, and a tarnished silver locket containing a pinch of salt from the Irish Sea, good for grounding and warding off unwanted influences.

As evening drew in, the rain finally eased, leaving behind a world of dripping drainpipes and glistening streets. The sky turned a bruised purple and orange. Kevin, showered and dressed in his newly enchanted suit, sat in his armchair, nursing a final mug of tea. Gripper was perched on his shoulder, preening his newly-stolen button. The house was quiet. The clock in the hall ticked towards seven. He had no idea if that was the appointed hour; it just felt right. He didn't feel brave or ready for a confrontation. He just felt a grim, Northern stubbornness setting in. He was Kevin Barlow, warlock of the back-streets. He fixed things. And if something in the wider magical world was broken, well, he’d at least have a look at it. He just hoped he didn't need his big wrench.

The grandfather clock in the hall didn't so much strike seven as toll it, each chime landing in the quiet room with the weight of a shovelful of earth on a coffin lid. On the seventh beat, the sound changed. It wasn't the metallic ring of the clock's bell, but a long, mournful whistle that seemed to come from everywhere and nowhere at once. It was the sound of a steam train, impossibly loud, impossibly close. The floorboards vibrated faintly, and the dregs in his teacup shivered, forming brief, concentric rings. Gripper stiffened on his shoulder, his head cocked, letting out a low, guttural croak of alarm. Kevin didn't move. He just closed his eyes and breathed out. "Show time."

The whistle faded, replaced by the distinct, pneumatic hiss of brakes and the gentle clatter of a carriage settling on its tracks. The sound was located, with unnerving precision, directly outside his front door. Not in the street, but flush against the peeling paint of the door itself. He stood, his knees cracking in protest. Gripper's claws tightened on the fabric of his jacket. He walked into the narrow hall and peered through the brass peephole, a small circle of distorted glass he'd installed himself after a run-in with some particularly persistent door-to-door goblin salesmen. The familiar, rain-slicked street wasn't there. Instead, he was looking at a section of railway platform, deserted save for a single, tall figure in a dark uniform.

Taking a steadying breath, Kevin turned the key and pulled the door open. It swung inwards not to the damp evening air of Wigan, but to the dry, artificially lit atmosphere of the platform he'd seen. A man in the crisp, severe uniform of an old-fashioned train conductor stood before him. The uniform was immaculate, a deep navy blue with silver piping that seemed to catch and hold the light. The man's face, however, was haggard, his eyes weary, as if he'd been making this same run for a thousand years. He held a silver ticket puncher in one gloved hand.

"Barlow, Kevin?" the conductor asked, his voice flat and devoid of any curiosity. "Invitation." Kevin held his hands out, palms up. "It was in a teacup. It's gone now." The conductor's gaze flickered to Kevin's forehead for a fraction of a second, his eyes briefly unfocusing as if he were reading a line of text. He gave a curt, satisfied nod. "Board, please. We are on a tight schedule."

Kevin stepped over the threshold of his own home and onto the platform, the transition seamless and deeply strange. He felt a faint, tingling sensation as he crossed, like walking through a curtain of static. Behind him, his front door swung shut with a solid click. He glanced back to see it was now just one of many identical carriage doors on a long, dark, impossibly sleek train. It had no engine he could see, and it stretched into the gloom at either end of the platform, which seemed to float in a void of swirling grey mist. Gripper, over his initial shock, gave an appreciative squawk at a gleaming brass handrail and made a hopeful lunge for it. Kevin caught him, tucking the bird more securely against his neck. "None of that. Try to act respectable for five minutes."

The conductor gestured him into the carriage. If the exterior was sleek and modern, the interior was a relic of a bygone age of travel. The compartment was lined with dark, polished wood and upholstered in deep red velvet. Small, frosted lamps on brass fittings cast a warm, steady glow, their light sourced from captured motes of will-o'-the-wisp that drifted lazily inside the glass. The air was thick with the scent of old leather, beeswax, and a faint, sharp tang of ozone. He was not the only passenger. A few seats away, a young woman with flyaway hair and wide, terrified eyes clutched a beaded handbag so tightly her knuckles were white. Her dress was a patchwork of different fabrics, shimmering faintly, and Kevin recognised the tell-tale signs of a dozen minor glamour charms stitched together to make a brave but fragile whole. She looked like a nervous sparrow that had accidentally flown into a cage of peacocks. Further down, a man in a brutally sharp suit of shimmering sharkskin stared out of the window, pointedly ignoring them both. He radiated an aura of smug, confident power, the kind that came from a prestigious magical academy and a fat family trust fund.

With a jolt so smooth it was barely perceptible, the train began to move. There was no rattle or clatter of wheels on tracks, just a silent, inexorable glide forward into the mist. Kevin took a seat opposite the nervous woman, placing his feet flat on the floor, trying to ground himself. He risked a look out of the window. The grey mist parted, but not to reveal the familiar landscape of Lancashire. Instead, he saw a rushing, chaotic panorama of the in-between. The soot-stained brick of a factory wall melted into the gnarled trunk of an ancient oak, which in turn dissolved into the glittering, data-stream of a fibre-optic cable before reforming as a stretch of cobbled road under a gaslight. It was the world's attic, the accumulated junk and memory of a nation, all flashing past the window in a disorienting, hypnotic blur.

The young woman opposite him jumped as a particularly vivid image—a screaming face from a forgotten silent film—flashed by. She caught Kevin’s eye and offered a watery, pathetic attempt at a smile. Kevin, who had planned on spending the journey in stony, unapproachable silence, found himself giving a small, almost imperceptible nod in return. He recognised the look in her eyes. It was the same look he saw in the mirror most mornings. The look of someone who was profoundly out of their depth and just trying to keep their head above water. The Umbral Ball hadn't even started, and he already wanted to go home.

The silence in the carriage was as thick and heavy as the velvet on the seats. The sharkskin-suited warlock continued to stare out the window, his reflection a sharp, predatory silhouette against the chaotic blur of the in-between. The young woman, meanwhile, looked as if she was trying to make herself as small as possible, as if hoping to physically shrink out of existence. Kevin found the quiet more unnerving than any magical threat; it was a loaded, judgmental silence. He cleared his throat, a sound like gravel being scraped across concrete.

"First time?" he asked, his voice rough from disuse. He directed the question to the young woman. Her head snapped up, her eyes wide with alarm, before she realised he was speaking to her. She gave a jerky, panicked nod. "I... yes. I'm Lily. From the Fens. I mostly just... help the marsh-herbs grow. I don't know why they've..." She trailed off, gesturing vaguely with a hand that trembled slightly. She clearly thought a mistake had been made. Kevin knew the feeling.

"Kevin. Wigan," he said, by way of introduction. "I mostly fix things." Before Lily could reply, a smooth, condescending voice cut across the carriage. "Fen-witches and boiler-menders. How wonderfully… rustic. The Covenant really is scraping the bottom of the barrel this decade." The man in the sharkskin suit had turned from the window. He had a handsome, sharp-featured face that was utterly ruined by a smirk of supreme self-satisfaction. He held a crystal tumbler in one hand, from which he took a slow, deliberate sip of what looked like pure, swirling starlight.

"They're broadening their base, I suppose," the man continued, not waiting for a response. "Embracing the provincial. It's all part of the new thinking. Very 'inclusive'. Personally, I think it dilutes the brand." He swirled his glass, the captured light within painting shifting patterns on his face. Gripper, perched on Kevin's shoulder, followed the movement with an unnerving intensity, his head tilted. He let out a low click, the magpie equivalent of a strategic assessment. Kevin put a hand up to his shoulder, a silent warning to the bird.

"And you are?" Kevin asked, his tone flat. He'd met men like this before, usually in management positions, men who used words like 'brand' and 'synergy' and had never done a real day's work in their lives. The smirk widened. "Julian Vayne. And unlike you, I'm here because I'm expected. Because my family has attended every Umbral Ball since its inception." He said the word 'family' as if it were a spell in itself, a ward against the common and the mundane. "Some of us understand that magic is about vision, about power, not patching up pipes and talking to pond-weed." He raised his glass in a mock toast. "To progress. To men like Alastor Blackwood, who aren't afraid to drag us out of the mud and into the modern age."

The mention of Blackwood's name made the carriage feel colder. Lily flinched, pulling her patchwork shawl tighter around her shoulders. Kevin's jaw tightened. So this was one of them. A Blackwood acolyte, a believer in the magic of filth and waste. "There's nothing modern about a landfill," Kevin said quietly. "It's just the same old rubbish, buried out of sight." Vayne let out a short, humourless laugh. "You wouldn't understand. You see rubbish. He sees a resource. Untapped. Infinite. The discarded energy of billions of souls. It's poetry."

As if summoned by the intensity of the argument, the lights in the carriage flickered. The motes of will-o'-the-wisp in their glass prisons began to dart about erratically, their gentle glow turning into a frantic, sickly green strobing. The smooth glide of the train became a shuddering, jarring motion, and a high-pitched squeal echoed from somewhere deep within the carriage's structure. Lily gasped, while Vayne scowled in annoyance, his drink sloshing over his hand. "Honestly," he muttered, "you can't get the staff these days." He stood up, steadying himself against a seat back. With a flourish, he made a complex gesture in the air, weaving a shimmering pattern of blue energy. "Silencio et stabilis!" he commanded, his voice ringing with power. The squealing noise intensified, and one of the light fittings exploded in a shower of glass and panicked light-motes, which zipped around the carriage like terrified insects before extinguishing themselves against the woodwork.

The carriage was plunged into semi-darkness, lit only by the remaining, frantic lamps and the swirling chaos outside the window. Vayne looked at his handiwork, his smug expression replaced by one of baffled fury. Lily, her eyes closed, was whispering a soft, rhythmic chant, and the shuddering of the train lessened fractionally, the raw panic in the air smoothing at the edges. It was helping, but it wasn't enough. It was like trying to calm a charging bull by singing it a lullaby. With a sigh that seemed to carry the weight of every plumber, mechanic, and IT support worker in history, Kevin stood up.

He ignored Vayne's spluttering and walked over to the ruined light fitting. He didn't produce a wand or chant an incantation. Instead, he reached into his jacket and pulled out his tool roll, unstrapping it to reveal his implements. He selected the metaphysical wrench. To Vayne's astonished eyes, it looked like nothing more than a common, greasy tool. Kevin placed his palm flat against the wall beside the fitting, closing his eyes. He wasn't looking for grand magical architecture; he was feeling for the plumbing. For the conduits that channelled the motive force of the train, for the ethereal wiring that powered the lights. He found it. A junction, right behind the wall, where two streams of power were supposed to merge. One was misaligned, bucking and kicking against the flow like a badly fitted pipe joint. Vayne's grand spell had been the equivalent of whacking it with a sledgehammer, making the leak worse.

Kevin fitted the head of the wrench over a point in the air that only he could see, a nut of solidified magic. He gave a firm, practiced twist. There was a dull, satisfying clunk, a sound no one else heard, but which he felt deep in his bones. The squealing stopped instantly. The train's motion smoothed out into its silent glide once more. The panicked will-o'-wisps calmed, their light returning to a steady, warm glow. With another tool, a small pair of pliers, he reached into the broken fitting, gently caught the stray, fizzing ends of the energy feed, and twisted them together. He wrapped them with a small strip of insulating tape he pulled from his pocket, a roll imbued with a minor ward of containment. The light inside the broken lamp flickered back to life, dimmer than the others, but steady. A make-do-and-mend repair.

He tucked his tools away and returned to his seat, the whole operation having taken less than thirty seconds. The carriage was silent again, but the quality of the quiet had changed. It was no longer judgmental; it was stunned. Lily was staring at him, her fear replaced by a look of profound astonishment and respect. Vayne was gaping, his crystal tumbler forgotten in his hand. He looked from his own manicured fingers, which had failed so spectacularly, to Kevin's, which were faintly smudged with soot from his enchanted charcoal. The mask of superiority had vanished, replaced by pure, unadulterated disbelief. "How… what was that?" he finally managed to ask.

"Leaky valve on the reality manifold," Kevin said, his face impassive. "Needed tightening." He settled back into his seat, placing his feet back on the floor. Gripper, who had watched the entire procedure with the rapt attention of an apprentice, gave a soft caw of approval and began attempting to preen Kevin's ear. The rest of the journey passed in a thick, awkward silence. Vayne didn't speak again, retreating behind a wall of sulky pride. Lily, however, kept glancing at Kevin with a newfound solidarity in her eyes. He was no longer just a fellow provincial; he was something else, something she hadn't known existed. A magician who fixed things.

Finally, the train began to slow. The chaotic scenery outside the window coalesced, the frantic energy drawing together and solidifying. The mist cleared, revealing not a station, but open air. They were impossibly high up, gliding towards a structure that defied both gravity and sanity. It was a palace, but one that looked like it had been grown rather than built, carved from the heart of a single, colossal geode. Its walls were towering, jagged facets of glittering amethyst and obsidian, catching the light of a swirling, star-dusted nebula that served as a sky. Bridges of pure, woven light connected its various spires, and waterfalls of shimmering dust cascaded down its sides into the endless void below. It was beautiful, terrifying, and the most ostentatious thing Kevin had ever seen. The train slid to a silent stop alongside a platform of polished black marble that jutted out from the palace's main entrance. The conductor's voice, as flat and emotionless as ever, echoed through the carriage. "Terminus. Welcome to the Umbral Ball." Kevin looked at the impossible palace, then down at the cuffs of his black polyester suit. He felt Gripper shift on his shoulder, the bird's beady eyes already scanning the glittering architecture for loot. He shared a brief, commiserating look with Lily. "Right then," he muttered, mostly to himself. "Here we go."

Stepping off the train was like stepping into a dream of a cathedral designed by a mathematician on hallucinogens. The air didn't smell of anything, yet it felt full, charged with a low thrum of power that made the fillings in Kevin’s back teeth ache. The black marble of the platform was so perfectly polished it reflected the swirling, star-dusted chaos of the nebula above, creating the unnerving sensation of walking on a captured piece of night sky. Other guests disembarked from similar, silent trains that arrived and departed with ghostly precision. They were a river of impossible fashion: a woman whose gown was made of living, iridescent moths that fluttered as she walked; a trio of warlocks in robes that shifted from black to deep space, revealing constellations in their folds; an old man whose long beard was woven with tiny, chiming bells of solidified sound. Julian Vayne, his earlier humiliation forgotten, immediately straightened his sharkskin suit and strode into the crowd, melting into the sea of ostentation like a shark returning to the water. He didn't spare Kevin or Lily a backward glance.

"Right," Lily whispered, her voice barely audible over the ethereal music that seemed to drift from the crystalline walls themselves. "Don't touch anything. Don't look anyone in the eye. Try to look like a plant." Kevin grunted in agreement, though his own strategy was less 'plant' and more 'grumpy bit of overlooked furniture'. They followed the flow of elegantly attired mages through a vast, arching doorway into the Great Hall of the palace. If the outside was breathtaking, the inside was simply bewildering. The ceiling was a dome of flawless amethyst, so high it seemed to have its own weather system. Pillars of what looked like frozen lightning supported the structure, pulsing with a soft, internal light. The room was filled with hundreds of magical beings, their conversations a low, melodic murmur punctuated by the occasional peal of silvery laughter. Floating trays navigated the crowd, offering guests goblets of shimmering nectar and small, intricate cakes that rearranged themselves into geometric patterns as you watched.

Kevin felt the weight of a thousand judging eyes. His suit, which had felt so substantial and serious in his Wigan living room, now seemed hopelessly drab and mundane. The coal-black fabric absorbed the palace's ambient light, making him a walking hole in the glittering tapestry of the ball. Lily fared slightly better; the homespun charms on her dress resonated with a certain rustic authenticity that some of the more nature-aligned mages seemed to appreciate with faint, condescending smiles. They found a relatively quiet spot near one of the frozen lightning pillars, Kevin trying his best to look like he was meant to be there, a task made more difficult by Gripper, who was vibrating with a combination of terror and avaricious glee on his shoulder. The magpie’s beady eyes were darting everywhere, cataloguing every glimmering earring, every sparkling cufflink, every stray mote of light.

He closed his eyes for a moment, pushing aside the visual and auditory assault, and focused on his own kind of senses. The air was a thick soup of power signatures. He could taste the ancient, earthy magic of the old-blood families, a flavour like rich soil and old wine. He could feel the sharp, frantic energy of the younger, ambitious mages, which felt like ozone and caffeine. And underneath it all, faint but unmistakable, was something else. A sour, chemical tang. The magic of Alastor Blackwood and his followers. It felt slick and unnatural, like the rainbow sheen of oil on a puddle. He scanned the room and saw them, a small, tight-knit group near the centre of the hall. They weren't wearing velvet or silk. Their clothes were severe, modern, made of strange, glossy fabrics. One man had a tie woven from what looked like shredded credit cards. A woman wore a necklace of polished, multi-coloured plastic bottle tops that gleamed like a barbarian queen’s jewels. They weren’t ostentatious in the same way as the others; their display was one of ideology. They stood apart, radiating a smug, disruptive confidence. The Plastimancer's disciples.

"Kevin Barlow?" The voice was dry, like rustling paper. Kevin opened his eyes. A tall, impossibly thin woman stood before them. She wore a severe, high-collared gown the colour of parchment, and her hair was pulled back so tightly it seemed to stretch the skin of her face. Her eyes, magnified by thick spectacles, scrutinised him as if he were a line item in a budget. He recognised the sigil pinned to her dress: the interlocking scales of the Covenant's administrative branch. "I am Proctor Sybil. We were… interested to see if you would answer the summons." Her tone implied she had wagered against it. Lily looked like she might faint.

"Didn't seem like I had much of a choice," Kevin replied, his voice coming out as a low rumble. "Invitation was a bit firm." Proctor Sybil did not smile. "The Covenant does not make suggestions. We were beginning to think your file was out of date. 'Provincial Hedge-Mage. Specialism: Metaphysical Maintenance and Damp-Related Curses'. It sounds so… quaint." Before Kevin could formulate a suitably sullen response, a sudden commotion erupted from the other side of the pillar. A portly warlock with a face like a startled plum let out a yelp of outrage, pointing a trembling, ring-laden finger at his own shoulder. "My familiar! My starlight sprite! It's gone!"

Kevin didn't need to look. He felt a familiar, triumphant flutter on his own shoulder, and a new, tiny point of bright, pulsing light was now nestled amongst the black feathers of Gripper's wing. The magpie had managed to snatch the warlock's familiar—a tiny, sentient ball of light—as it flitted past. He had it pinned under his gimpy foot and was peering at it with intense, scientific curiosity. Kevin groaned internally. This was exactly the kind of attention he didn't want. He acted on instinct, his movements quick and economical. "Sorry, mate, I think you dropped this," he said, turning to the apoplectic warlock. As he turned, his hand shot up to his shoulder in a movement too fast for most to follow. His thumb and forefinger, calloused from years of working with tools, deftly plucked the tiny, terrified sprite from Gripper's grasp. With the other hand, he reached into his pocket and produced a dull brass button—the one Gripper had been playing with earlier. In a single, fluid motion of misdirection worthy of a back-street card sharp, he palmed the button into Gripper's claws and presented the rescued sprite back to the warlock on his open hand.

The whole thing took two seconds. The warlock, baffled, stared at the trembling ball of light in Kevin's palm, then back at his own empty shoulder. "Oh! Well. I... thank you," he stammered, his anger deflating into confusion. He gently scooped up his familiar and retreated, shooting Kevin a suspicious look. Proctor Sybil had missed none of it. A flicker of something that might have been surprise or even faint approval crossed her severe features. "Quick hands. A useful, if low-brow, skill." She adjusted her spectacles. "Your file also mentions an aptitude for 'applied mundanity'. An ability to work with the base, tangible elements of the world. Brick, iron, soot… the things our more 'visionary' members despise." Her gaze flickered meaningfully towards Blackwood's followers. "The Covenant has a pest problem, Mr. Barlow. A new breed of vermin that thrives on decay and disposability. We've spent centuries drawing power from ancient, noble sources. Now we are faced with a man who can pull an army out of a rubbish tip."

The cold knot in Kevin's stomach tightened. So that was it. It was about Blackwood. He wasn't here by mistake. He was here as a potential exterminator. "And you think I can do something about that?" he asked, the absurdity of it almost making him laugh. "I fix boilers. I unblock drains. I'm not a bloody demon hunter." "No," Proctor Sybil agreed, her voice dropping lower. "You are not. You're a craftsman. Blackwood's power is one of mass production and pollution. He twists the mundane. We need someone who understands it, who respects it. Someone who can get their hands dirty." She looked him up and down, her gaze lingering on his soot-black suit and his work-worn hands. "The Umbral Ball is not just a party, Mr. Barlow. It is a muster. A gathering of assets. We are assessing our resources. And you, for better or for worse, are one of them. Now, if you'll excuse me, I must ensure the chronomantic champagne is being served at the correct temporal temperature." With a final, sharp nod, she turned and glided away, disappearing into the glittering throng, leaving Kevin and Lily standing in the shadow of the lightning pillar, the weight of the summons suddenly a hundred times heavier than before.

The Proctor's words hung in the air between them long after she had gone, a pronouncement as cold and sharp as the facets of the amethyst ceiling. A pest problem. An exterminator. Kevin felt a sudden, desperate urge for a mug of strong tea and a bacon butty. The shimmering nectar floating past on enchanted trays looked thin and unsatisfying, like drinking a perfume advert. Lily had gone a pale shade of green that clashed horribly with the rustic charms on her dress. She looked at him, her eyes wide. "They can't be serious. An asset? You? Us? I talk to reeds, Kevin. I persuade voles not to eat the rare bog-orchids. I'm not a soldier."

"Tell me about it," Kevin muttered, running a hand over his face. The whole situation felt like a nightmare he'd have after eating bad cheese. "They've got it wrong. They've read the file, but they haven't understood it. I'm the bloke you call when the magical damp gets in the walls, not when there's a dark lord rising. It's a different skillset." He stared out at the swirling vortex of power and privilege that was the Umbral Ball. Hundreds of the most powerful mages in the country, and they were looking to him for help. It was like asking a bicycle repairman to fix a space shuttle because they both had wheels. It made a horrible, bureaucratic kind of sense, and that was the most terrifying part.

His gaze fell again on the group of modernists, Blackwood's acolytes. He watched them now with a new, professional interest, the way he'd watch a patch of rising damp or a flickering light fitting. They weren't mixing. They kept to themselves, a sleek, black-clad island in the sea of colour and tradition. Their power felt different up close, too. It wasn't just the chemical tang; it had a texture. It was smooth, non-porous, and repetitive. It was the energy of a billion identical plastic bags, a million disposable coffee cups. It was a magic of quantity over quality, a smothering, featureless tide of power harvested from the things no one wanted but everyone had. It was cheap, it was nasty, and it was everywhere. It was, he realised with a jolt, the antithesis of everything he held to. His own Wigan magic was about history, about the specific, stubborn spirit of a single brick that had seen a hundred years of rain, or the memory held in a piece of iron forged in a local foundry. Blackwood's magic had no history. It was born in a factory yesterday and would be in a landfill tomorrow, yet its essence would linger for a thousand years.

A sudden change in the hall’s atmosphere broke his concentration. The gentle, melodic music faltered, replaced by a discordant hum. The soft, ambient light from the lightning-pillars began to pulse erratically, casting long, dancing shadows that made the revellers look like frantic puppets. In the centre of the hall, a magnificent fountain that had been cycling crystalline water up into an ever-changing ice sculpture sputtered and died. The sculpture hung in the air for a moment before crashing to the marble floor with a sound like a thousand breaking chandeliers. A collective gasp went through the crowd. This fountain wasn't just decorative; Kevin could feel it now that it was broken. It was the heart of the palace's environmental controls, the regulator for the very air they were breathing. The air was already growing thin and cold, the low thrum of background power fading to a worrying silence.

Panic, barely held in check, began to ripple through the guests. Several of the old-blood warlocks strode towards the fountain, their faces masks of grim determination. One, a man with a beard of woven starlight, unleashed a torrent of pure, silver energy at the fountain's base. It struck the basin and splashed off harmlessly, like water off a duck's back. Another conjured complex, glowing runes in the air, attempting to diagnose the fault, but the runes flickered and died, unable to get a reading. They were throwing raw, immense power at the problem, but the problem wasn't a lack of power. Kevin knew this instinctively. This was a blockage.

He moved closer, Lily trailing nervously in his wake. He edged his way through the crowd of gawking, helpless mages until he could see the fountain's basin clearly. The crystal water that remained was murky, and floating on its surface, almost invisible, was a thin, greasy film. It was a sheet of solidified, malevolent apathy. Blackwood's magic. It wasn't a curse they could break or a ward they could shatter. It was metaphysical pollution. It had coated the delicate workings of the fountain, insulating it from all magical influence, clogging it like grease in a drain. The grand, powerful spells of the high mages were useless, like trying to unblock a sink with a thunderstorm.

"This is pathetic," a voice sneered from nearby. It was Julian Vayne, a look of contempt on his face. "All this ancient power, and they can't even keep the lights on. Blackwood would have this place running with ten times the efficiency." He wasn't wrong, Kevin thought grimly. Blackwood would have it running, but the cost would be a slow, choking poison. He looked at the failing system, at the panicked, powerful mages, at the spreading film of magical waste. He felt a familiar, weary sense of obligation settle over him. It was the same feeling he got when Mrs. Higgins called him about her television again. It wasn't his job, not really. But no one else knew how to fix it, and if he didn't, things would only get worse.

With a deep sigh of resignation, he turned to Lily. "Right. I might need a hand. Can your magic… persuade things to rot? To break down?" Lily looked from Kevin's determined face to the chaos at the fountain. "Organic things, yes. I don't know about… that." "It's all the same, in the end," Kevin said, more to convince himself than her. "Just chemicals. Give it a go when I tell you." He pushed the last few feet to the fountain's edge, ignoring the indignant looks from the velvet-clad warlocks. He knelt, his knees protesting on the hard marble, and peered into the basin. Proctor Sybil was there, her face a rigid mask of fury, directing the failed efforts. Her eyes met Kevin's, and in them, he saw a flicker of desperate hope. He didn't offer a grand pronouncement. He just took off his jacket, folded it carefully, and handed it to a stunned Lily. Then he rolled up his sleeves.

Ignoring the gasps of the assembled mages, he plunged his hands into the cold, filmed water of the fountain. The magical pollution felt slick and cold, like touching a dead thing. It resisted him, its nature inherently passive and stubborn. He couldn't blast it, so he wouldn't try. He closed his eyes, sinking his senses past the suffocating film, feeling for the machinery beneath. He found the primary intake valve, a complex lattice of crystal and focused light, now gummed shut. He reached into his tool roll, which he had tucked into his waistband, and brought out his metaphysical wrench. He fitted it over the point of blockage, a nexus of grimy, congealed energy. He strained, putting his back into it. It was like trying to turn a nut that had been rusted solid for a century. It wouldn't budge. Raw force wasn't the answer. He needed a solvent.

"Lily. Now," he grunted, his arms trembling with the effort. Lily, her face pale but determined, knelt beside him. She placed her hands just above the surface of the water, not touching the filth. She began to hum, a low, earthy tune that smelled of damp soil and fallen leaves. It was a song of decay, of the patient, relentless work of mycelium and bacteria. It was the antithesis of Blackwood's sterile, eternal plastic magic. As she hummed, the greasy film on the water began to change. It thinned, losing its integrity. Tiny fissures appeared in its surface as Lily's organic magic began to un-make it, to persuade it to decompose. It was working. The rust was weakening.

Kevin felt the shift instantly. He took a fresh grip on his wrench and heaved. This time, with a deep, grinding groan that vibrated through the floor, the metaphysical nut turned. There was a great sucking sound, and the greasy film was pulled down into the newly opened intake valve. The fountain roared back to life, a column of pure, clean water shooting twenty feet into the air before freezing into the shape of a soaring eagle. The lightning-pillars glowed with a steady, brilliant light once more, and the celestial music swelled, clear and triumphant. The air grew warm and breathable again. A cheer went up from the crowd. Kevin pulled his arms from the basin, dripping crystal water onto the marble. He had done it. He had fixed it. He stood up, wiping his wet hands on his trousers, feeling the exhausted satisfaction of a job well done. And as the crowd parted, he saw him. Across the hall, standing amongst his followers, was a man with a sharp, charismatic smile and eyes as dead and grey as discarded packaging. Alastor Blackwood. He wasn't smiling anymore. He was looking directly at Kevin, his expression one of cold, calculated appraisal. The provincial hedge-mage from Wigan had just announced himself, and in doing so, had accepted an invitation to a fight he never wanted.

The immediate aftermath of the fountain's repair was, for Kevin, far worse than the crisis itself. A wave of relieved, excited chatter swept through the hall. Mages who, minutes before, would have walked through him as if he were a particularly uninteresting ghost now turned to stare. He saw grudging respect in the eyes of the old-blood traditionalists, and naked, avaricious curiosity from the younger power-brokers. They looked at him not as a person, but as a newly discovered tool, a strange implement they didn't understand but could see a use for. He felt horribly exposed, like a rare and ugly beetle pinned to a collector’s board. He wiped his dripping hands on his trousers, the mundane action a small anchor in the sea of arcane wonder. Lily handed him back his jacket, her hands still trembling but her eyes shining with a fierce, protective pride.

That fragile moment of victory was shattered as the crowd before them seemed to part, not with force, but with a kind of weary deference. Alastor Blackwood was approaching. He moved with a liquid grace that was entirely at odds with the rigid, almost brutalist cut of his suit, a garment woven from a material that looked like solidified oil slick. His disciples flanked him, a silent, watchful entourage whose collective gaze felt like being surveyed by security cameras. As he drew closer, the ambient magic in the air seemed to thin and sour, the rich, complex notes of history and power replaced by a flat, sterile hum. Gripper, on Kevin’s shoulder, let out a low, angry hiss, his feathers puffing up as if facing a predator. The bird, a creature of instinct and old earth, knew poison when he saw it.

"Kevin Barlow," Blackwood said, his voice a smooth, reasonable baritone that belonged on a corporate training video. He stopped a few feet away, a perfect smile fixed on his handsome face. "The warlock of Wigan. I've read your file. A fascinating piece of archival data. It’s a pleasure to see such artisanal magic in practice. A real heritage skill. Like watching a man thatch a roof in the age of drone-built housing." The compliment was perfectly shaped, and perfectly insulting. It framed Kevin not as a contemporary, but as a museum piece, a charming anachronism. He gestured vaguely at the now-pristine fountain. "You fixed a leak. Commendable. But I'm not interested in patching the old, failing systems. I'm interested in replacing them entirely. Why struggle to keep a thousand-year-old aqueduct flowing when you can have clean, efficient, modern pipes carrying a million times the volume?"

Kevin met his gaze. Blackwood's eyes were the most disturbing thing about him. They were clear, intelligent, and utterly empty, the grey of a worn-out carrier bag. He felt the Northern stubbornness rise in him, a bulwark against the man's slick charisma. "Because the aqueduct remembers the rain," Kevin said, his voice a low growl. "Your pipes only remember the factory. You're not building anything new, you're just repackaging the old and selling it cheap. There's a difference between power and energy. You've found a lot of energy. But it's got no substance. No soul. It's the ghost of a meal in a plastic tub. It'll fill a space, but it'll never feed you." He knew it was a clumsy analogy, but it was his. It was the truth as he understood it.

Blackwood’s smile didn't falter, but it tightened at the edges, the bonhomie turning brittle. "Soul? Memory? Oh, you really are a relic. Those are legacy concepts, Mr. Barlow. Inefficient. They hold us back. The future isn't about memory; it's about data. It's about volume. The world throws away its energy every second of every day, and I am the only one with the vision to collect it. The tide of progress is rising, made of everything they discard. You are standing on a quaint little brick wall of your own making, telling the ocean to go back. It won't." His voice dropped, losing its public-relations warmth and taking on a sharp, dangerous edge. "Don't stand in the way of progress. You'll only get your feet wet. Or worse." Around them, the plastic bottle tops on his follower's necklace pulsed with a sickly, uniform light, a silent chorus of menace.

Before Kevin could reply, a third voice cut through the tension, as sharp and dry as a closing ledger. "The Covenant has bylaws regarding overt threats on consecrated ground, Mr. Blackwood." Proctor Sybil had reappeared at Kevin's elbow, her posture rigid, her magnified eyes fixed on the Plastimancer. "And your… unlicensed experiment with the Grand Orrery Fountain has been noted." Blackwood’s smile finally vanished, replaced by a look of mild irritation, as if a dull but persistent legal obstacle had presented itself. He gave a slight, almost imperceptible shrug. "Just a stress test, Proctor. To demonstrate the fragility of the current infrastructure. My point has been made, I think." He looked back at Kevin, his eyes sweeping over him one last time, a final, dismissive assessment. "It was… educational, Mr. Barlow. Do enjoy the rest of the ball." With a nod to the Proctor, he turned and glided away, his entourage closing ranks and following him back into the heart of the party, a slick of darkness moving through the light.

The moment he was gone, the air seemed to rush back into Kevin’s lungs. He hadn’t realised he’d been holding his breath. He felt a tremor in his hands, the lingering effects of adrenaline and a deep, instinctual revulsion. The grand, glittering party now felt like a battlefield, and he had just survived the first skirmish. Lily placed a steadying hand on his arm. "Are you alright?" she whispered, her voice full of concern. He just nodded, unable to speak. His quiet, predictable world of damp curses and pixie infestations had been irrevocably breached. Proctor Sybil adjusted her spectacles, her expression unreadable. "You see now, Mr. Barlow," she said, her voice devoid of any sympathy. "The nature of the pest. He believes you are a quaint inconvenience. It is imperative, for all our sakes, that he remains wrong." She looked from his soot-black suit to his work-stained hands, and for the first time, her expression held something other than administrative disapproval. It was a look of grim, calculating necessity. "Your presence is no longer just required at the ball. Your service is now required by the Covenant."

Service. The word landed in the opulent hall with the dull, final thud of a closing cell door. It wasn't a request. It was a draft notice. Kevin looked from Proctor Sybil’s severe, unblinking face to the glittering, oblivious crowds of the Umbral Ball. Just an hour ago, his biggest problem had been the structural integrity of his cheap suit. Now, he was apparently the magical world's last line of defence against a man who wanted to turn it into a metaphysical landfill. The faint, coppery tang of a spent cantrip he was so used to smelling in his kitchen was now overwhelmed by the stench of a looming disaster, and he was being handed the mop.

"Now is not the time for discussion," Proctor Sybil stated, her voice leaving no room for argument. She made a subtle, sharp gesture, and a section of the crystalline wall beside them shimmered and became translucent, revealing a narrow, dark corridor that hadn't been there a moment before. It was a service passage, the kind of hidden route that staff used in stately homes. Even in a palace grown from a geode, there were still back stairs. "This way. Both of you." She looked pointedly at Lily, who jumped as if zapped with a minor static charm. Kevin felt a brief, bitter kinship with the worn armchair back in Wigan; he was being commandeered, repurposed for a function he was never designed for. He followed the Proctor into the darkness, Lily scurrying at his heels. The bright music and light of the ball faded behind them, replaced by a humming silence and the faint, earthy smell of the palace's deep foundations.

The corridor opened into a chamber that was the antithesis of the grand hall. It was a workshop, a control room. The walls were unpolished, raw crystal, but they were covered in complex, glowing diagrams of the palace's internal structure. Conduits of captured starlight ran like plumbing along the ceiling, and in the centre of the room, a deep pool of perfectly still, dark water acted as a scrying glass, reflecting not the ceiling but a slow, swirling image of the palace's core. The hum was stronger here, a deep, resonant bass note that felt ancient and powerful. This was the engine room, the boiler room. For the first time since arriving, Kevin felt a flicker of something other than dread: a grudging, professional interest.

Proctor Sybil gestured towards the pool. "The Heart of the Geode," she said, her voice tight with suppressed urgency. "The palace is not merely a structure; it is a focus. It sits at the confluence of three major ley lines. The Heart draws from them, regulating and distributing that power." The image in the pool shifted, showing the three brilliant white lines of energy flowing into a central, pulsating sphere of light. But as they watched, dark, greasy tendrils crept along the ley lines, like sludge coating the inside of a pristine pipe. "Blackwood's sabotage of the fountain was a feint. A diagnostic. While our most powerful mages were distracted, his followers were planting these… parasites. Magical limpets, for lack of a better term. They are made of solidified waste, of discarded plastic energy. They are latching onto the ley lines, insulating them from the Heart."

She pointed to a spot where one of the tendrils had fully encircled a ley line. The brilliant white of the line flickered and died, and a corresponding section of the glowing diagrams on the wall went dark. "He is severing our power supply. Once he has starved the Heart, he will attempt to connect his own power source—a ghastly accumulator fed by the psychic residue of a billion discarded items. He intends to steal the entire palace, to turn this nexus of ancient power into a battery for his disposable magic. Our attempts to blast the parasites off have failed. Raw power only seems to feed them, or splashes off their inert surfaces. We cannot touch them." She finally turned to Kevin, her gaze intense and devoid of all pleasantries. "But you can. Your magic is… base. It is of the earth, of tangible things. You do not deal in pure energy; you deal in substance. His parasites are substance. They are a physical problem, a metaphysical blockage. You are a craftsman, Mr. Barlow. We need you to clear the pipes."

The request, as absurd as it was, settled in Kevin's mind with a horrible clarity. They weren't asking him to fight a warlock. They were asking him to do a plumbing job on a cosmic scale. The thought was so profoundly, terrifyingly mundane that he almost laughed. He thought of the Northern Conclave, of the flooded car park, of the sheer, panicked chaos his magic could unleash when applied to something too large for it. He was being set up to fail, to be the scapegoat when this all went wrong.

"You've got the wrong man," he said, the words coming out as a flat, tired statement. "This is like asking me to fix a leak at a nuclear reactor with a roll of duct tape and a spanner. My magic is for keeping the damp out of a two-up two-down, not for wrestling with ley lines. I'll make it worse. Trust me. I am spectacularly good at making things worse." He held up his hands, showing her the calluses and the faint scars. "These are for fixing things you can kick, Proctor. Things made of iron and brick. This… this is something else. You need an archmage, not a handyman."

Sybil's expression didn't soften. "The archmages have failed," she snapped, her composure finally cracking to reveal the raw desperation beneath. "They are trying to perform surgery with battleaxes!" She strode to one of the raw crystal walls and placed her hand on it. The scrying pool rippled, and the image shifted, zooming in on one of the parasites. It was a lumpy, ugly thing of fused plastic, pulsing with a slow, sickly light. As they watched, a bolt of pure, white magic, unleashed by some distant warlock, struck it. The parasite absorbed the energy, swelled slightly, and seemed to grip the ley line even tighter. Sybil turned back, her face grim. "Your magic is not a battleaxe, Mr. Barlow. It is a wrench. It is a file. It is a well-aimed hammer. You said it yourself: Blackwood's power has no soul, no history. It is a thing. You are a warlock who works with things. We are asking you to do your job. To fix what is broken. Are you truly telling me, as a craftsman, that you are willing to stand by and watch this happen because the scale is intimidating?"

The appeal was a low blow, and it landed perfectly. It bypassed his fear and his resentment and hit the one thing he couldn't deny: his professional pride. He was a fixer. He couldn’t stand a leaky tap, let alone a failing universe. He looked at the ugly, parasitic growth, the metaphysical equivalent of a tumour of fat in a drainpipe. He hated it. He hated its cheapness, its filth, its smug, stubborn reality. And he knew, with a sinking feeling in the pit of his stomach, that he had to at least try. He let out a long, weary sigh that seemed to carry the weight of every thankless repair job he had ever undertaken.

"Fine," he bit out. "Fine. But I do this my way. No archmages looking over my shoulder. No one telling me I'm doing it wrong. I need access to the primary conduits, and I'll need her." He jerked his head towards Lily, who looked as if she was about to be sick. "Her magic helped before. It rots things. This stuff," he gestured at the parasite in the pool, "deserves to rot." He looked back at Sybil, his eyes hard. "And when this is over, you and me are going to have a long talk about my service contract. Starting with hazard pay." He unbuttoned his jacket, preparing to take it off again. Gripper, sensing the shift from talk to action, ruffled his feathers and let out a sharp, clicking sound, his beady eyes fixed on the glowing diagrams on the wall as if looking for the quickest thing to steal. The work was about to begin.

Proctor Sybil gave a single, sharp nod, her expression a mask of grim resolve. For a woman who likely spent her days navigating arcane bureaucracy and temporal audits, the situation had clearly been escalated far beyond her preferred operational parameters. She turned and led them not towards the grandeur of the palace, but to a plain, almost invisible seam in the raw crystal wall. With a press of her long, thin fingers against a specific point, the seam widened into a doorway, revealing a passage that was the polar opposite of the glittering hall they had just left. It was narrow, dusty, and lit by the functional, unadorned glow of the power conduits that ran along its walls like exposed plumbing. The air was cool and smelled of ozone and ancient, undisturbed stone. It was a workman’s entrance, and Kevin felt a sliver of comfort in its unapologetic utility. He felt more at home here, in the guts of the palace, than he had at the party.

"The primary distribution nexus is this way," Sybil said, her voice echoing slightly in the confined space. "It is where the three ley lines are braided before being fed into the Heart. It is the most vulnerable point." She strode ahead, her parchment-coloured gown looking absurdly out of place against the rough-hewn walls. Lily followed, her eyes wide as she took in the raw, untamed power pulsing from the conduits. Gripper, however, seemed to relax on Kevin's shoulder, letting out a series of soft, appreciative clicks. The bird, a creature of hidden spaces and functional clutter, found the corridor far more to his liking than the intimidating openness of the ball. It was a space full of promising nooks and potentially valuable, overlooked junk.

They arrived in a small, circular chamber, a hub where three enormous conduits, each as thick as a grown man's waist, converged on a central, multifaceted crystal junction. The light within them was sluggish, the brilliant white of the ley lines dimmed and polluted by the dark, parasitic growths they could now see clearly, even without the aid of a scrying pool. They were ugly, lumpy masses, clinging to the conduits like cancerous barnacles, their plasticine sheen a deep insult to the living light they were strangling. Kevin walked forward, ignoring Sybil’s sharp intake of breath, and placed a hand on the central junction. It was cool to the touch, where it should have been radiating warmth. He closed his eyes, extending his senses down the flow, feeling the blockages, the pressure drop, the sickly, inert texture of the parasites. It was a bad clog, a systemic failure waiting to happen.

"Right," he said, opening his eyes and turning to Lily. He was in his element now, a master craftsman surveying a job. His voice held a new authority, the easy confidence of someone who knows his tools. "I need your help. That rot-song you were humming out there, it works. It's a solvent for this plastic rubbish." He pointed to the nearest parasite. "I'm going to open a channel, tap directly into the feed. I need you to pour that magic of yours straight down the pipe. Don't think of it as a ley line. Think of it as a blocked drain, and that thing is a big lump of grease and hair. You're the chemical unblocker. Just focus on making it fall apart." He placed his right hand flat against a maintenance panel on the junction, a small, square plate covered in archaic runes. He then held out his left hand to Lily. "Put your hand on mine. I'll act as the conductor. Just push it all through me."

Lily looked terrified, but she also looked at the ugly, encroaching darkness, and a spark of the Fens' stubborn defiance lit her eyes. She took a deep, shaky breath and placed her small, trembling hand on Kevin's. The connection was instant. He felt her magic, not as a raw force, but as a cool, damp, living thing, full of the scent of wet earth, moss, and the patient, endless cycle of decay and rebirth. It was a quiet, insidious power, and it was perfect. "Okay," he grunted, closing his eyes and focusing. With a mental push, he opened the channel. He visualised a valve turning, a direct line from them to the first parasite. Lily gasped as she felt the pull, her magic being drawn from her, through Kevin, and into the massive conduit. She began to hum again, her eyes closed in concentration, her song a low, mournful, and strangely beautiful melody of entropy.

Proctor Sybil watched, her hands clasped so tightly her knuckles were white, as a faint, greenish-brown light flowed from Lily, through Kevin's arm, and into the junction. The brilliant white of the ley line inside the conduit flickered, and a wave of murky colour travelled down its length, washing over the first parasite. On the outside, the ugly plastic mass began to sweat a greasy, black film. Its smooth surface pitted, then cracked, tiny fissures spreading across it like a shattered windscreen. It was working. The un-magic of Blackwood, designed to be eternal and unchanging, was being taught the concept of its own mortality. Lily’s power wasn’t destroying it with force; it was reminding it that everything, eventually, falls apart.

"It's brittle," Kevin said through gritted teeth, the effort of channelling Lily's alien magic making his muscles ache. "But it won't fall off on its own. It needs persuading." He let go of Lily's hand, the circuit broken. She swayed, looking drained but triumphant. He reached into his tool roll and pulled out a tool that made Proctor Sybil recoil slightly. It was, to all appearances, a simple, rusty crowbar, the kind you'd use to pry open a packing crate. But in Kevin's hands, it was more. It was the physical embodiment of leverage, of every stubborn nail pulled, every jammed door forced, every resistant object made to yield. He wedged the tip of the crowbar into a metaphysical crack he could now perceive between the weakened parasite and the conduit. It wasn't a physical act, not entirely, but it required physical effort. He took a stance, bent his knees, and put his entire weight into it.

A horrific, high-pitched screech, like a thousand nails on a blackboard, echoed through the chamber. The crowbar glowed with a dull, angry red as it strained against the parasite’s unnatural grip. Kevin’s face was a mask of pure, stubborn effort. This was magic as manual labour, a world away from the elegant gestures and whispered words of the high mages. This was brute force, intelligently applied. With a final, guttural roar of exertion, he heaved backwards. There was a deafening crack, like a falling tree, and the parasite tore free from the conduit. For a moment it hung in the air, a dead, crumbling thing, before it dissolved into a cloud of foul-smelling dust that was instantly whisked away by the chamber's ventilation spells.

Instantly, the conduit flared with brilliant, clean, white light, its proper flow restored. A corresponding section of the diagram on Sybil's scrying pane flashed from red to green. Kevin slumped against the wall, breathing heavily, the crowbar clattering to the floor. He was drenched in sweat, every muscle screaming in protest. One down. He looked at the diagrams glowing on the wall, at the dozens of other red lights indicating the other parasites. He had done it. He had proved it could be done. And in doing so, he had committed himself to the most exhausting, thankless job of his entire life. He caught Proctor Sybil's eye. Her face, for the first time, was stripped of all arrogance and authority, leaving only a look of raw, unadulterated awe. He offered her no words of triumph, just a weary, long-suffering stare that said, far more eloquently than words, "Now do you see?"

There was no applause, no ceremony. The only sounds in the nexus chamber were Kevin’s ragged breathing and the clean, powerful hum of the restored conduit. Proctor Sybil stared, not at Kevin, but at the glowing green light on her impromptu scrying pane, as if she couldn’t quite believe the data her own eyes were providing. Then she looked at the rusty crowbar on the floor, at Kevin slumped against the wall, covered in sweat and grime, and at Lily, pale but resolute, standing beside him. The calculations in her head were almost audible, a swift and brutal reassessment of everything she thought she knew about the practical application of power.

"Water," she said, her voice clipped and efficient, the awe already being compartmentalised and processed into a plan of action. She spoke into a small, intricate silver brooch pinned to her collar. "Get water to Nexus Chamber Alpha. And tea. Strong. Two sugars. Milk." A brief pause. "And a plate of bacon sandwiches. Immediately." The order, so mundane and so specific in this place of cosmic wonder, was more shocking than any incantation. It was an acknowledgement. It was a concession. She understood. This wasn't a battle to be won with starlight and ancient rhymes; this was a long shift, and the workers needed fuel. Kevin managed a weak, grateful nod. Maybe this service contract wouldn't be so bad after all.

The work fell into a grim, exhausting rhythm. A tray of food and a large, steaming pot of proper, builders-grade tea arrived via a silent, floating disc, and after a brief, ten-minute break where Kevin devoured three sandwiches with a single-minded focus that unnerved the Proctor, they began again. The process became a practiced, if painful, ballet. Kevin would assess the parasite, feeling for its weak points. Lily, her confidence growing with each success, would place her hand on his, her rot-song weaving a dissonant harmony with the hum of the ley lines. Kevin would channel her power, directing it with a plumber’s precision, then take up his crowbar and, with a grunt and a curse, perform the metaphysical extraction. They were a team, a two-person crew of arcane sanitation engineers, their movements becoming more synchronised and efficient with each blockage they cleared.

Sybil became their foreman, her administrative mind perfectly suited to logistics. She monitored the palace's energy grid, calling out the coordinates of the next parasite, prioritising the blockages that were causing the most critical power drains. She kept their tea mugs full and ensured a steady supply of magically-chilled water. At one point, seeing the strain on Kevin’s face, she disappeared for five minutes and returned with a small, heavy pot filled with a grey, viscous paste. "Artificer's Balm," she explained, a hint of professional pride in her voice. "A proprietary Covenant formula for soothing strained metaphysical connections. And bruised knuckles." The balm, when rubbed into Kevin’s aching hands and shoulders, felt like ice and fire, chasing away the worst of the pain and leaving a deep, steadying warmth.

Of course, it was too good to last. After they had cleared the fifth parasite, they came across one that felt different. The slick, inert surface they had grown used to was gone. This one was covered in sharp, crystalline spines, and it pulsed with a frantic, aggressive energy. When Lily began her song, the parasite fought back. It emitted a high-frequency shriek that sent waves of pain through their skulls, and the spines glowed with a malevolent, purple light. Lily’s rot-magic, which had worked so well before, seemed to slide off the crystalline surface, unable to find purchase. Gripper, who had been contentedly trying to pry a loose crystal from the wall, let out a screech of his own and flattened himself on Kevin's shoulder, his small body trembling.

"He's learning," Kevin grunted, stepping back and rubbing his temples. "He knows what we're doing. He's adapting." This wasn’t just a passive blockage anymore; it was an active defence. They couldn't dissolve it, and trying to pry it off with the crowbar while it was still fully energised would be like trying to perform dentistry on a live shark. He looked at the thing, his mind churning, sifting through his unconventional arsenal. He needed an abrasive. Something to scour the defensive shell, to give Lily’s magic a foothold. His eyes fell on the soot-blackened fabric of his suit jacket, draped over a nearby rock. An idea sparked, born of desperation and deep familiarity with his own strange brand of power.

He walked over to his jacket and, to Sybil's utter bewilderment, began scraping at the sleeve with a small, sharp-edged rock. A fine black powder, the same charcoal dust he had used to dye the suit, came away in his palm. It wasn't just charcoal; it was the essence of a thousand winter nights in a Wigan pub, saturated with the stubborn, smoky memories of arguments, laughter, and shared warmth. It was grit, in every sense of the word. "Stand back," he said, walking towards the spiny parasite. He took a deep breath and, with a sharp, forceful puff, blew the dust from his palm. The black powder didn't just float; it shot forward in a directed cloud, striking the parasite. There was no explosion, no grand flash of light. The dust simply coated the crystalline spines, clinging to them. The angry purple glow dimmed, and the high-pitched shriek faltered. The ancient, stubborn history in the soot was acting as a buffer, a grounding agent against the parasite's frantic, modern energy.

"Now, Lily!" he yelled. Lily, seeing her chance, focused her will and unleashed her song with a renewed ferocity. This time, the green-brown light of her magic found purchase on the grit-dusted spines. The crystals began to dull, to crumble at the edges, the structure losing its integrity. The shriek died completely, and the parasite sagged, its defences broken. Kevin grinned, a grim, tired expression. He picked up his crowbar. "Right, you stubborn git," he muttered, wedging the tip into a newly formed crack. "Let's be having you." This time, the extraction was almost easy. The weakened parasite came away with a groan and dissolved into a shower of corrupted dust and soot.

A new sense of hope filled the chamber. They had faced Blackwood’s counter-move and beaten it. Sybil was looking at the soot on Kevin's jacket with the intensity of a gemologist examining a flawless diamond. They had a system. They had a counter for the counter. They could win this. But as they moved towards the central junction to tackle the largest and final parasite, the one wrapped around the very heart of the nexus, the atmosphere in the chamber turned icy cold. The humming of the conduits dropped to a dead, flat tone. A voice, smooth, amplified, and dripping with condescending amusement, echoed from the walls around them. It was Blackwood.

"Impressive," the voice of the Plastimancer resonated, seeming to come from nowhere and everywhere at once. "Truly impressive. A little light housekeeping. I must say, Mr. Barlow, you are proving to be a more tenacious stain than I anticipated." As he spoke, the final parasite began to glow, not with the angry purple of the spined one, but with a cold, intelligent, silvery light. It pulsed in time with his words. "But you're just a janitor. A cleaner. You can scrub away the symptoms, but you cannot cure the disease. The disease is the past. It's this entire, inefficient, crumbling system you're fighting to protect." The voice was inside their heads now, a slick, persuasive whisper. "Why are you doing their dirty work, Kevin? The Covenant. The 'old blood'. They despise you. To them, you're just the help. A grubby-handed tradesman they sneer at behind their velvet sleeves. They use you, and when this is over, they'll discard you like one of my own products."

"Join me," the voice purred, dripping with synthetic reason. "Your magic, your understanding of the mundane, it has… potential. It's wasted on them. I can give you real power. We can build a new world, a clean, efficient world, free from the dusty, sentimental baggage of history. No more damp. No more rust. A world where everything is new, forever. You wouldn't be a fixer anymore, Kevin. You'd be an architect." The temptation was insidious, a perfectly crafted appeal to Kevin's own resentments, to his place as an outsider. He felt a flicker of agreement, a poisonous whisper in his own mind that said *he's not wrong*. He saw Sybil looking at him, her face suddenly pale with a new kind of fear, the fear of betrayal. He looked at the final, master parasite, glowing with a hypnotic, promising light, and then he looked down at his own hands, calloused, smudged with soot and Artificer's Balm. He thought of his small kitchen, of the chipped Blackpool mug, of the stubborn, familiar reality of his life. A world where everything was new forever sounded like hell.

He took a deep breath, the air tasting of ozone and lies. He looked up at the ceiling, as if addressing Blackwood directly. "You can stuff your new world," Kevin Barlow said, his voice a low, gravelly counterpoint to Blackwood's seductive whisper. "I like the damp. I like the rust. It's honest. It's what happens. There's nothing more disposable than something that promises to last forever." He spat on the floor, a gesture of profound, Northern contempt. "Now, are you going to shut up, or am I going to have to come and find you after I've unblocked this last drain?"

For a long moment, the only sound was the echo of Kevin’s defiance fading into the stone. Then, a new sound began, a low, grating noise like a thousand plastic bottles being crushed at once. Blackwood’s voice, when it came again, had lost all its persuasive charm. It was cold, flat, and full of a vast, industrial rage. "A mistake, Mr. Barlow. A sentimental, thermodynamically inefficient mistake." The master parasite, the great, pulsating growth wrapped around the central junction, began to transform. Its smooth, silvery surface hardened, turning a glossy, obsidian black. The light within it changed from a hypnotic glow to the hard, dead white of a fluorescent tube in a derelict warehouse. It was no longer just a blockage; it had become an engine of hostile intent.

The very air in the chamber became a weapon. It grew thick and suffocating, tasting of burnt plastic and stale air conditioning. The steady, clean hum of the restored conduits was drowned out by a discordant, high-frequency whine that vibrated deep in their bones, making their teeth ache and their thoughts scatter. Dark, oily tendrils of energy, tangible as smoke, began to lash out from the parasite, whipping against the walls and floor, leaving scorch marks on the ancient stone. Sybil, with a sharp cry, threw up a hand. A shield of shimmering, golden hexagons flickered into existence around them, deflecting the worst of the blows, but it shuddered with each impact, a visible crack appearing in the pattern.

"He's trying to overwhelm the nexus's localised wards!" she shouted over the din, her face a mask of furious concentration. "He's using the raw, unfiltered energy of the ley line itself, twisting it before it can be refined by the Heart!" This wasn't a subtle act of sabotage anymore; it was a full-frontal assault. Blackwood was done with subtlety. He was trying to smash the system from the inside out. Lily, her face ashen, tried to begin her song of decay, but the overwhelming sonic assault disrupted her concentration, her notes faltering and breaking. The sterile, inhuman noise of Blackwood’s power was the antithesis of her living magic; it was like trying to sing in a hurricane.

Kevin scrambled for his crowbar, his mind racing. Brute force wouldn't work, not against this. The parasite was no longer just a passive lump; it was an active, malevolent intelligence. Trying to pry it off now would be like trying to crowbar a live transformer from its housing. He needed a different tool, a different approach. He stared at the thing, trying to see past the lashing tendrils and the blinding light, trying to understand its mechanics. He saw it then, at the very centre of the obsidian mass, protected by layers of hardened plastic and whipping energy. It was a single, small object, no bigger than his thumb. It was a perfectly smooth, lenticular disc of polished, hyper-condensed plastic that shone with a captured, internal light. It was the processor. The brain. The one unique, irreplaceable part in a system built on disposable uniformity. It was the thing that controlled the chaos.

His eyes darted from the gleaming core to the cowering, terrified shape of Gripper on his shoulder. The magpie’s head was tucked under his wing, but one beady eye was still open, fixated on the single, impossibly shiny object at the heart of the maelstrom. In that moment of desperate clarity, a plan bloomed in Kevin's mind, a plan so absurd, so profoundly unprofessional, that it had to work. He grabbed Gripper, his hand closing gently but firmly around the bird’s trembling body. He brought the magpie up to his face, looking him directly in the eye. Gripper let out a panicked squawk, but Kevin held him fast.

"Listen to me, you feathered menace," Kevin said, his voice low and urgent, cutting through the chaos. "You see that? The shiny bit. The really, really good one. In the middle of all the nasty stuff." He pointed with his chin, forcing the bird to look. Gripper’s eye locked onto the target, his terror momentarily eclipsed by a wave of pure, unadulterated, avian avarice. He let out a soft, covetous click. "I know you want it," Kevin continued, his voice a conspiratorial whisper. "You want it more than you've ever wanted a bottle top. More than Mrs. Higgins's wedding ring. It's the shiniest thing in the whole world. You go and get it for me. Get the shiny bit, Gripper. BRING IT TO ME." He opened his hand. For a second, the magpie hesitated, caught between abject terror and the overwhelming, primal instinct of his species.
